choices.C: The MYTAB table is created in the USERS tablespace but no rows can be inserted into the table by USER02.
choices.E: The MYTAB table is owned by the SYS user.
choices.A: The MYTAB table is created in the SYSTEM tablespace but no rows can be inserted into the table by USER02.
choices.D: The CREATE TABLE statement generates an error because the SYSDBA privilege does not provide any space quota on the SYSTEM tablespace by default.
choices.B: The MYTAB table is created in the SYSTEM tablespace and rows can be inserted into the table by USER02.

discussion.content:
A&E are correct. 

As mentioned in previous comments, since user02 is connecting with sysdba admin privilege the current user connected will be SYS and not user02. SYS user owns the system tablespace so the MYTAB table will be created in the SYSTEM tablespace. Now, to test whether user02 can insert into the table, you have to connect without SYSDBA admin privilege (i.e conn user02/us123) 

Since user02 was not granted the insert object privilege on the MYTAB table owned by sys, the user user02 cannot insert rows into the table. 

Some people are most likely confirming B because they are attempting the insert without switching from the SYS user to USER02.

comments.content: I would also add that it is not advisable to grant users privileges on objects in the system tablespace. Also, it is not advisable to create objects in the system tablespace as well.
SYSDBA role once granted comes with its own set of privileges which include creating table. Hence A is wrong. Answer is B and E

discussion.content:
I think A
when as sysdba show user = sys

comments.content: When you connect with an administrative privilege, you connect with a current schema that is not generally associated with your username. For SYSDBA, the current schema is SYS.Also, when you connect with an administrative privilege, you connect with a specific session user. When you connect as SYSDBA, the session user is SYS. ref: https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ADMIN/dba.htm#ADMIN11048
A&E It can insert because user is SYS , if use CONN user02/us123 AS SYSDBA , I try use show user values USER is "SYS" , if use CONN user02/us123 , show user values USER is "USER02" I can't insert.

questions.question_text: You use multiple temporary tables frequently in your database. Which two are benefits of configuring temporary undo? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Correct Answer is A and B

choices.A: Performance improves because less redo is written to the redo log.
choices.D: Performance improves because no redo and undo are generated for the temporary tables.
choices.B: Temporary undo reduces the amount of undo stored in undo tablespaces.
choices.C: Performance improves because data manipulation language (DML) operations performed on temporary tables do not use the buffer cache.

choices.D: It checks for required tablespaces and if they are not available, creates them automatically.
choices.E: The preupgrade_fixups.sql script is executed automatically to fix issues in the source database.
choices.C: A log file, preupgrade.log, is created that contains the output of the Pre-Upgrade Information tool.
choices.A: It generates a script to recompile invalid objects post-upgrade.
choices.F: The postupgrade_fixups.sql script is created to address issues that can be fixed after a database has been upgraded.
choices.B: The preupgrade_fixups.sql script is created to list and describe issues in the source database.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about the Pre-Upgrade Information Tool? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Correct is BCF. 

The utlrp.sql is used to compile invalid objects (not specifically generated by the pre-upgrade tool) 
The pre_upgrade_fixups is not executed automatically but can be run manually.

See ref: https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/12.2/upgrd/using-preupgrade-information-tool-for-oracle-database.html#GUID-0C496815-1826-4E28-8437-36FA549000F9

Selected Answer: BCF
The Pre-Upgrade Information Tool (preupgrade.jar) creates the following files:
-A log file (preupgrade.log):The log file contains the output of the Pre-Upgrade Information Tool.
-The pre-upgrade fixups: preupgrade_fixups.sql
-The post-upgrade fixups:postupgrade_fixups.sql
The preupgrade tool itself does not make changes to your database to correct errors. However, it does generate scripts that you can use to correct identified errors.

Selected Answer: BCF
BCF
running preupgrd.sql against the database being upgraded will generate 3 files
preupgrade.log
preupgrade_fixups.sql
postupgrade_fixups.sql

I think the correct answer should be: ABC (not E, but B.)
Because pre_up_fix.sql is run by hand.

choices.B: creation of a fine-grained audit policy
choices.A: execution of SQL statements by users connected with the SYSDBA privilege

questions.question_text: Which activity is audited by default and recorded in the operating system audit trail irrespective of whether or not database auditing is enabled?

discussion.content:
A
SYSDBA and SYSOPER logins. Oracle Database records all SYSDBA and SYSOPER connections.

BDE Is right
A is about expired not obsolete

A backup is obsolete when REPORT OBSOLETE or DELETE OBSOLETE determines, based on the user-defined retention policy, that it is not needed for recovery. A backup is considered expired only when RMAN performs a crosscheck and cannot find the file. In short, obsolete means "not needed," whereas expired means "not found."

choices.A: The backup sets marked as expired are deleted.
choices.D: The physical files related to the backup are deleted automatically.
choices.C: The physical files related to the backup need to be manually deleted.
choices.B: The information related to the backups is removed from the recovery catalog and the control file.
choices.E: The backups deleted are based on the backup retention policy.
